content:
Nelson Bighetti is a professor of artificial intelligence at the Stanford AI Lab. His research interests include distributed robotics, mobile computing and programmable matter. He leads the Robotic Neurobiology group, which develops self-reconfiguring robots, systems of self-organizing robots, and mobile sensor networks.

title: Nelson Bighetti

content:
Publications  Mario D. Molina, Nancy Chau, Amanda Rodewald, and Filiz Garip (2022). “How to model the weather-migration link: A machine-learning approach to variable selection in the Mexico-U.S. context”. Journal of Ethnic and Migration Studies [article]
 Molina, Mario, Victor Nee, and Hakan Holm (2022), “Cooperation with strangers: Spillover of community norms”. Organization Science [article] [replication package]
 Garip, Filiz and Mario D. Molina (2021), “Network amplification”, Research Handbook on Analytical Sociology (edited by Gianluca Manzo). Edward Elgar: Massachusetts. [book]
 Molina, Mario D., Mauricio Bucca, & Michael W. Macy (2019), “It’s not just how the game is played, it’s whether you win or lose”. Science Advances, vol. 5, eaau1156. [article] [replication package]
(Press Coverage by The Associated Press, ZME Science, The New Scientist, and the Cornell Chronicle).
 Molina, Mario & Filiz Garip (2019), “Machine learning for sociology”, Annual Review of Sociology, vol. 45. [article] [preprint]
 Molina, Mario (2013) “Unity between Sensibility and Understanding. The Origin of the Critical Problem” (in Spanish), Revista de Filosofia, vol. LXIX, 195-213. [article]
  Work in Progress  Molina, Mario D., “To rest on your laurels: Status dynamics and cooperation”. (Revising manuscript)
 Occhiutto, Nicholas and Mario D. Molina. “The Social Structure of Asset Bubbles: The Case of the Taxicab Medallion in New York City.” (Revising manuscript)
 Drouhot, Lucas, Mario D. Molina, and Filiz Garip, “Identity and relational structure among immigrant adolescents in Western Europe”. (Writing)
 Asad, Asad, Neil Jr. Lewis, and Mario D. Molina, “Profiles of psychological distress among noncitizens in the United States, 2011-2018”. (Data analysis)
